questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the gastroenterology clinic with a six-month history of recurrent abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, and unintentional weight loss. He describes experiencing frequent urgency to defecate, especially after meals. Endoscopy findings reveal aphthous ulcers and skip lesions in the terminal ileum and colon. Which of the following markers is most useful in the diagnosis of this condition?

A 13-year-old boy presented to the pediatric clinic with a chronic history of bloody diarrhoea and delayed growth. Lab investigations were positive for antibodies to Escherichia coli outer membrane protein C (OmpC), I2, and anti-flagellin (anti-CBir1). What implications does this serologic profile have for the patient’s disease course?

options.label: A
options.text: Reduced risk of aggressive CD progression

options.label: B
options.text: Potential for more severe disease and shorter time to complications

options.label: D
options.text: Unlikely progression to CD based on serologic markers

questions.correct_answer: B. Potential for more severe disease and shorter time to complications
questions.explanation:
Serological Markers in Crohn's Disease (CD)

Serological Markers in Ulcerative Colitis (UC)

1. Anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies (ASCAs):

  • Found in approximately 60-70% of CD patients.
  • Lower prevalence (10-15%) in UC patients.
  • Associated with increased risk of small bowel involvement and fibrostenosing disease phenotype.

1. Perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (pANCAs):

  • Positive in around 60-70% of UC patients.
  • Much lower prevalence (5-10%) in CD patients.
  • Associated with increased risk of UC development and may aid in differentiating UC from CD.

2. Antibodies to Escherichia coli outer membrane porin protein C (OmpC):

  • Positive in about 55% of CD patients.
  • Linked to more aggressive disease behaviour and internal penetrating complications.

2. Other Antibodies:

  • While less commonly used, serological markers like anti-colon antibodies have been investigated in UC but are not as clinically impactful as pANCAs.
  • ASCA (Anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibody)

3. Antibodies to bacterial homologs (I2 and anti-CBir1):

  • I2 antibodies are found in 50-54% of CD patients.
  • Anti-CBir1 antibodies are identified in approximately 50% of CD patients.
  • The presence of these antibodies may indicate a more aggressive disease and a shorter time to complications.
